background_dashed.customLabel: In Adolescents (13-19 years old),  participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of TECH on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 15 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old),  participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of TECH on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adults (>=20 years old),  participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of TECH on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  participants, there is no difference between TECH and controls on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adolescents (13-19 years old),  participants, there is a very strong effect in favor of  TECH on Adaptive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of TECH on Language (Expressive skills). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  participants, there is no difference between TECH and controls on Language (Receptive skills). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old),  participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of controls on Disruptive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 3 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.
